infotips.asymmetry: Your deviation from perfect 50/50 L/R balance. Under 2.5% is pro level.

infotips.te: Percentage of power going forward. Aim for 70-80% ‚Äî higher isn't always better.
infotips.ps: How even your power is through the pedal stroke. Aim for 20%+. Elite cyclists hit 25%+.
infotips.zones: Time spent in optimal (green), attention (yellow), and problem (red) zones.
infotips.timeInZone: Time spent in each zone. Green is optimal, yellow needs attention, red is a problem.
infotips.score: Overall technique rating combining balance, TE, and PS. Higher is better.
infotips.lastAchievement: Date of your most recent achievement.
infotips.milestone: Name and description of the achievement.
infotips.category: Type of milestone (Volume, Balance, Technique, etc.).
infotips.weeklyActivity: Number of rides per day. Aim for 3-5 rides per week for steady progress.
infotips.compRides: Number of rides compared to last week.
infotips.compHours: Total saddle time. More hours equals more training adaptation.
infotips.compDistance: Total kilometers ridden. Useful for tracking volume alongside hours.
infotips.compClimb: Total elevation gained. Over 2000m per week builds climbing strength.
infotips.compBalance: Power asymmetry vs last week. Lower is better, negative is improvement.
infotips.compOptimal: Time in optimal zone vs last week. Higher is better technique.
infotips.perfScore: Overall technique score from 0 to 100. Higher means better form.
infotips.perfOptimal: Time with all metrics in the green zone. Higher is better.
infotips.perfPower: Average power output in watts. Higher at same HR means better fitness.
infotips.perfEnergy: Total energy in kilojoules. Roughly equals calories burned.
infotips.technique: Pedaling efficiency metrics. TE is power transfer, PS is stroke smoothness.
infotips.balanceFatigue: Left vs right power split. Changes indicate fatigue or compensation.
infotips.fatigueTrend: Overall fatigue trend. Stable is good pacing, dropped is overexertion.
infotips.balanceTrend: Left/right balance trend over time. Consistent values near 50% indicate good symmetry.
infotips.techniqueTrend: Technique metrics trend over time. Look for steady improvement patterns.
infotips.compTe: Torque Effectiveness vs last week. Positive change is improvement.
infotips.compPs: Pedal Smoothness vs last week. Improves slowly, small gains matter.
infotips.fatigue: Technique at ride start vs end. Dropping values indicate fatigue.
infotips.teFatigue: TE change during ride. Drop indicates muscular fatigue.
infotips.psFatigue: PS change during ride. Usually first metric to drop when tired.
infotips.powerAvg: Average power in watts. Track over time to measure fitness gains.
infotips.powerMax: Peak power achieved. Useful for sprints and FTP estimation.
infotips.np: Normalized Power adjusts for surges. Close to average means steady effort.
infotips.cadence: Pedal revolutions per minute. Optimal is 80-95 rpm for most riders.
infotips.hrAvg: Average heart rate. Lower at same power means better fitness.
infotips.hrMax: Peak heart rate reached. Near max often hurts technique.
infotips.speed: Average speed. Less reliable than power due to terrain and wind.
infotips.elevationGain: Total elevation gained. Over 1000m is a serious climbing workout.
infotips.elevationLoss: Total elevation lost. Should match gain on loop rides.
infotips.grade: Maximum gradient. Above 10% is steep, above 15% is very steep.
infotips.energy: Total energy output. Plan nutrition at 250-300 kcal per hour.
infotips.trendCurrent: Value from your most recent ride in this period.
infotips.trendAverage: Average value across all rides in the selected period.
infotips.trendSpread: Difference between best and worst. Lower spread means more consistent form.
infotips.trendLatest: Value from your most recent ride for this metric.
infotips.trendBest: Best value in the period. For asymmetry lower is better, for TE/PS higher is better.

infotips.tableAsym: Power asymmetry percentage. Lower means more balanced power output.
infotips.tableZones: Time distribution across optimal, attention, and problem zones.

accountData.title: Account Data

accountData.note: We do not have access to your Google password. Authentication uses OAuth 2.0.

fields.psPurpose: How smooth your pedal stroke is (%)

userSettings.title: User Settings (Synced if Signed In)
userSettings.intro: When signed in, your app settings are synced between your Karoo device and web dashboard:

fields.thresholdsPurpose: Balance threshold, TE optimal range, PS minimum
fields.alertPrefsPurpose: Which metrics trigger alerts, vibration/sound/visual options
fields.screenWakePurpose: Whether alerts wake the Karoo screen
fields.bgModePurpose: Collect data even when data field is hidden

userSettings.note: Settings sync allows you to configure thresholds on the web and have them apply on your Karoo automatically. If not signed in, settings remain local only.

fields.drillTimestampPurpose: When the drill was done and how long it took
fields.timeInTargetPurpose: How long you maintained target metrics

achievements.title: Achievements (Synced if Signed In)
achievements.intro: When signed in, your unlocked achievements are synced:

localOnly.title: Data Stored Only on Your Karoo (Never Synced)
localOnly.intro: The following data is stored locally on your Karoo device and is never sent to our servers:

fields.ratingsPurpose: 1-5 star ratings you assign to rides
fields.notesPurpose: Personal notes you add to rides
fields.onboardingPurpose: Whether you've completed the app tutorial

localOnly.note: This data remains on your device. If you uninstall the app, this data is deleted.

dontCollect.intro: While we collect performance metrics for analysis, we specifically avoid location and tracking data:
dontCollect.note: Your rides cannot be traced to specific locations. We only store aggregate performance metrics, not where you rode.

usedNotStored.title: Data Used But Not Stored
usedNotStored.intro: The following data is read in real-time for display purposes but is never saved to device or cloud:

fields.smoothedPurpose: Real-time trend indicators for live display
fields.rawStreamPurpose: Individual data points are processed and discarded; only per-minute averages are stored

permissions.title: Android Permissions
permissions.intro: The KPedal app requests the following permissions on your Karoo:

fields.foregroundPurpose: Run in background to collect data during rides
fields.notificationsPurpose: Show alerts when pedaling technique needs attention
fields.bootPurpose: Start automatically when Karoo powers on

permissions.note: No internet, location, camera, microphone, or storage permissions are requested.

step1.title: Power Meter Pedals
step1.desc: Your pedals transmit balance, TE, and PS via ANT+ Cycling Dynamics protocol to your Karoo.

step2.title: KPedal App on Karoo
step2.desc: The app processes real-time data locally at ~20Hz, calculates averages, and stores ride summaries in local database. Up to 100 rides are kept on device; older rides are auto-deleted.

step3.title: Cloud Sync (Optional)
step3.desc: If signed in, ride summaries and settings are synced to KPedal cloud via HTTPS. Only aggregated data is sent ‚Äî no raw sensor streams. Settings changes on web are automatically applied to your Karoo.

step4.title: Web Dashboard
step4.desc: View your ride history, trends, and analytics at app.kpedal.com. Data is retrieved only for your authenticated account.

dataFlow.offlineDesc: The KPedal app works fully offline. You can use all features without signing in or syncing. Data stays on your device.

infrastructure.title: Infrastructure
infrastructure.workersUse: API processing (serverless). Request logs stored ~7 days.
infrastructure.d1Use: SQLite database for users and rides

security.title: Security Measures
security.jwtDesc: Signed tokens with 15-minute expiry for access, 7-day for refresh
security.rateLimitDesc: Auth: 10 req/min, API: 100 req/min, Sync: 30 req/min. Uses IP address for counting, auto-deleted after 60 seconds.
security.validationDesc: All data validated and sanitized before storage
security.csrfDesc: OAuth state verification prevents cross-site attacks

local.drillResultsPeriod: Until app uninstall (also synced to cloud if signed in)
local.achievementsPeriod: Until app uninstall (also synced to cloud if signed in)
local.settingsPeriod: Until app uninstall (synced to cloud if signed in)

google.title: Google OAuth
google.desc: Used for sign-in only. We request minimal scopes: openid, email, profile.

cloudflare.title: Cloudflare
cloudflare.desc: Our infrastructure provider. Handles API, database, and web hosting.

notUsed: Google Analytics or any analytics service
Facebook Pixel or any advertising tracker
Crash reporting services (no Firebase Crashlytics, Sentry, etc.)

balance.title: Power Balance
balance.desc: Left/right power distribution. Pro cyclists maintain within 2%. Imbalances above 5% increase overuse injury risk and waste energy through compensation patterns.

te.title: Torque Effectiveness
te.desc: Percentage of power applied during the effective part of stroke. Based on Wattbike research ‚Äî higher is NOT better. Above 80% can actually reduce total power output.

ps.title: Pedal Smoothness
ps.desc: How evenly power distributes through the entire pedal stroke. Eliminates "dead spots". Elite cyclists achieve 25-35% ‚Äî this is the hardest metric to improve.

q1.q: Which power meter pedals are compatible?
q1.a:
Full support (Balance + TE + PS): Garmin Rally, Favero Assioma, SRM X-Power, PowerTap P2.
Balance only: Wahoo POWRLINK, Stages LR, 4iiii Precision, Rotor INpower.
Any pedal transmitting ANT+ Cycling Dynamics will work.

q2.q: How do I install KPedal on my Karoo?
q2.a:
Option 1: Download APK from GitHub Releases ‚Üí transfer via USB ‚Üí open file manager on Karoo ‚Üí tap to install.
Option 2: Open the GitHub release link directly in Karoo's browser and download.
Option 3: Use ADB: adb install kpedal.apk

q3.q: Do I need to add KPedal data fields to my ride screen?
q3.a: No. With Background Mode enabled, KPedal collects metrics for ALL rides automatically ‚Äî even if you never add a single data field. Data fields are optional and only for viewing metrics live during the ride. Your complete ride history is saved regardless.

q4.q: What is considered a "good" power balance?
q4.a: 48-52% (¬±2% from 50/50) is optimal. Most professional cyclists ride with 1-3% natural asymmetry. Don't obsess over perfect 50/50 ‚Äî it's nearly impossible and not necessary. Focus on consistency within your range rather than chasing perfection.

q5.q: Why is 70-80% Torque Effectiveness optimal and not higher?
q5.a: Based on Wattbike research: above 80% TE, you're likely over-pulling on the upstroke. This wastes energy and can actually reduce total power output. The 70-80% range indicates you're applying force efficiently through the pedal stroke without fighting yourself on the recovery phase.

q6.q: What exactly does Pedal Smoothness measure?
q6.a:
Formula: PS = (average power √∑ peak power) √ó 100.
Higher PS means more consistent power application through the pedal stroke. 20%+ is good for most cyclists. Sprinters typically have lower PS (explosive, punchy power), while endurance riders tend toward higher values.

q7.q: How is the Ride Score calculated?
q7.a:
Weighted formula: Balance (40%) + TE (35%) + PS (25%).
Each metric is scored 0-100 based on time spent in optimal zones.
85+ = Excellent technique
70-84 = Good, minor areas to improve
Below 70 = Significant room for improvement

q8.q: How do the guided Drills work?
q8.a: Drills are structured exercises with real-time targets displayed on screen. Example: "Single Leg Focus" asks you to maintain 55-60% balance on one leg for 30 seconds. KPedal tracks your time-in-target and provides a score at the end. Perfect for warmups, recovery rides, or dedicated technique sessions.

q9.q: Can I create my own custom drills?
q9.a: Yes. Custom Drills let you define your own phases, targets, and durations. Create drills tailored to your specific weaknesses ‚Äî maybe a 45-second high-TE focus followed by 30-second balance work. Your custom drills are saved locally and sync to cloud.

q10.a:
Configurable thresholds:
‚Ä¢ Balance: asymmetry exceeds your set limit (default 5%)
‚Ä¢ TE: drops below minimum (default 60%)
‚Ä¢ PS: drops below minimum (default 15%)
Alerts use vibration + beep. Cooldown (15s-2min) prevents spam. You can enable/disable each metric independently.

q11.q: Does KPedal work without internet connection?
q11.a: 100% yes. All core features ‚Äî data collection, drills, alerts, ride history ‚Äî work completely offline. Cloud sync is optional and only activates when you enable it. Your data is always stored locally on the Karoo first. Sync happens automatically when you're back online.

q12.q: Will KPedal drain my Karoo battery?
q12.a: Minimal impact: ~1-2% extra per hour during active rides. KPedal only runs data collection while you're riding. Between rides, only a tiny listener waits for ride start ‚Äî negligible power consumption. Heavily optimized for efficiency.

q13.q: Can I sync data across multiple Karoo devices?
q13.a: Yes. Link multiple Karoos to your account. Settings sync between them automatically. All rides from all devices appear in one unified dashboard. Perfect if you have a backup Karoo, race and training devices, or upgrade to a new unit.

q14.q: How does the Achievement system work?
q14.a: Achievements unlock as you hit milestones: ride count, total hours, consistency streaks, technique improvements. Examples: "Iron Balance" (10 rides with <2% asymmetry), "Century Club" (100 rides tracked). Achievements sync to cloud and display on your web dashboard.

q15.q: Can I use KPedal with Garmin, Wahoo, or other bike computers?
q15.a: No. KPedal is built specifically for Hammerhead Karoo using their official karoo-ext SDK. It accesses ANT+ Cycling Dynamics data, native alert system, and ride state monitoring ‚Äî deep integrations not available on other platforms.

q16.q: Is my data private and secure?
q16.a: Yes. Data stays on your Karoo unless you enable cloud sync. Cloud uses Google Sign-In ‚Äî we never see or store your password. No tracking pixels, no ads, no data selling. The entire project is open source ‚Äî audit the code yourself on GitHub.

q17.q: Why does my balance change at different power outputs?
q17.a: This is normal. At low power, slight technique variations are amplified. At high power, you tend to recruit muscles more evenly. Many cyclists see 2-3% more asymmetry at endurance pace vs threshold. KPedal tracks this so you can identify patterns and work on weak spots.

q18.q: How often should I do technique drills?
q18.a: 2-3 times per week is a good starting point. Include them in warmups (5-10 min) or dedicate recovery rides to technique work. Consistency matters more than volume ‚Äî regular short sessions beat occasional long ones. Track progress via drill scores over time.
